Reading input with System.in

Suppose we have the following class. This main method should read input one line at a time, and print it out with line numbers: 

package lab8;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class LineNumberer
{
  public static void main(String[] args)
  {
    Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
    int lineCount = 1;

    while (scanner.hasNextLine())
    {
      String line = scanner.nextLine();
      System.out.print(lineCount + " ");
      System.out.println(line);
      lineCount += 1;
    }
    
    System.out.println("Done");
  }
}

Try creating and running this in Eclipse. Click in the Console pane and then type a few lines. Each line that you type is echoed back to the console preceded by a line number. When you get tired of doing this, you can normally type Ctrl-Z (on OS X or Linux, use Ctrl-D) to signal that there will be more input. However, due to a bug in Eclipse, you might have to first click in another pane, and then click back in the console pane again. (If this doesn't seem to work, use the red button.)

Delimiters and nextLine()

We know that by default, a scanner uses whitespace as the delimiter between items of input. Notice that in the example above, the delimiters are being ignored. Even if you type a sentence with spaces in it, the scanner will return the entire line of text.

This is an example of a case in which the input is organized in the form of lines of text rather than individual words or numbers. The purpose of the methods hasNextLine() and nextLine() is to read input one line at a time, rather than one word or item at a time.

It would be much more useful to run this program on a file, rather than on typed input.
